ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: HyperNeat
ygData.msgSnippet: Now that I think more about it, I fully agree that it is probably better to get the activation node output (or node bias) from the same CPPN. For example, if

Now that I think more about it, I fully agree that it is probably better to
get the activation node output (or node bias) from the same CPPN. For
example, if you wanted a repeating sub-module that included different
activation functions, those activations should  come from the CPPN
generating that sub-module. Otherwise we are more or less back to a direct
encoding (or, a generative encoding trying to appropriately map onto a
separate generative encoding that is changing across evolutionary time).

Very cool that you have already tested it and it works. :-)




Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
517.214.1060




> From: Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Sat, 19 Jan 2008 21:40:39 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: HyperNeat
> 
> I've read through all the messages on this thread and Luca can
> correct me if I'm wrong but I believe that what Colin suggested is
> what Luca also means to suggest, i.e. that CPPNs could in some way
> define the activation functons in the substrate as well as the
> connection weights.
> 
> That's a good question and several people have touched on ways to do
> this.  My view is that the best way is to include a separate CPPN
> output that determines activation functions in the same CPPN that
> defines connection weights.  It is true that that output is
> overspecified because it returns a value for 4 inputs instead of 2,
> but you can just make a convention that you only read it e.g. when
> the last two are both (0,0).  Note that this is just an arbitrary
> convention, but it removes the overspecification.  The reason I think
> this approach is better than coevolving is that the mathematical and
> geometric reltationships that describe the regularities in the
> connection weights end up in the hidden nodes of the CPPN, and these
> very same relationships are likely relevant to the pattern of
> activation functions in the substrate as well.  So if you separate
> out the CPPN that determines activation functions, then it cannot
> take advantage of what is known internally from generating connection
> weights, and vice-versa.
> 
> We have already tried this approach as a way of generating node
> biases (which is sometimes an important capability) and we have found
> it to work effectively.  That is, the node bias is determined by a
> second CPPN output that is read for the node at x1 y1 when x2=0 and
> y2=0.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Hi Colin-
>> 
>> That does make sense. It would be really cool to see how either of
> those
>> suggestions works. Even cooler would be a comparison of the two. My
> guess is
>> that the separate, co-evolved strategy would work better because it
> would be
>> less constrained.
>> 
>> Do you have any test problems in mind? Problems that require the
> use of many
>> different types of activation functions?
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> 
>> jclune@...
>> 517.214.1060
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>>> From: Colin Green <locster01@...>
>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Date: Sat, 19 Jan 2008 16:18:50 +0000
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: HyperNeat
>>> 
>>> Luca,
>>> 
>>> Are you suggesting a fixed network structure? And then we get the
> activation
>>> function for each node by querying a CPPN?
>>> 
>>> 
>>> Technically CPPN would be the wrong term there but hopefully you
> all
>>> understand what I mean. Ken and others, another way of looking at
> it is that
>>> the CPPN as well as outputting connection strength between two
> nodes, also
>>> outputs a value which tells us what activation function to use
> (although
>>> each connection has two end points of course). A better way to do
> this might
>>> be to have an entirely separate co-evolved genome that describes
> a network
>>> that accepts a single substrate coordinate and outputs parameters
> for a
>>> parameterised activation function. Make sense?
>>> 
>>> Colin.
>> 
> 
>
